awd_titl_txt: III: Small: Collaborative Research: Modeling Pre- and Post- Conditions for Understanding Events
awd_abstract_narration:
This project develops new algorithms for learning the typical pre-conditions and post-conditions of real-world events. These logical conditions are crucial for developing better language understanding applications that can reason precisely about situations described in written text. There have been significant technological advances in the automatic understanding of text, but event reasoning requires knowledge that is often unstated and implicit. For example, if a meeting is canceled, it would be unusual for the text to say that the meeting was scheduled to happen (a pre-condition), and that it will now no longer happen (a post-condition). While these are obvious to a human, these conditions are unknown and crucial to building assistive technology. This kind of reasoning can enable complete document understanding, support precise and explainable question answering, and improve the output of language generation. This project has broad applications to a variety of assistive technology for information access and understanding for the general public. Learning pre-conditions can further educational text exploration applications by explaining how a certain situation came about. Better language understanding can also help explain automated decisions, making technology more trustworthy in mission critical domains. And finally, this project will help address the shortage of talent in the critical areas of computer science and machine learning by training graduate and undergraduate students.
 
This project focuses on developing both the models to learn pre- and post-condition relations, but also the large datasets required to enable this learning. The first thrust in the project plan is to develop new datasets of conditional knowledge, and then to develop initial supervised learning algorithms to detect them in text. The project will initially focus on today’s large-scale language models to establish competitive baselines that the rest of the project will improve upon. After creating these annotated datasets and baselines, the focus will then turn to developing generative neural architectures like variational autoencoders that are augmented with rich structured latent spaces. These spaces will be augmented with entity networks that allow it to track generic event knowledge, but also specific knowledge about the entities. The motivation for generative models is to aggregate condition knowledge from large collections of unlabeled text as well. Finally, in addition to developing large scale datasets to learn this knowledge, the project will develop new reasoning tasks that could spur the community to develop more precise language understanding models, and to use these tasks to further research into richer models of event knowledge. All scientific findings, datasets, and other artifacts of the research will be made available for the scientific community and the broader public.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Intelligent agents must be able to understand how events alter and shape the world. This requires them to, at the very least, understand what enables (or hinders) some events (pre-conditions), and what the effects (post-conditions) some events have on the state of the world. For example, consider an event where a person visits another country. For this event to happen, there are multiple preconditions such as obtaining a visa (in some cases) and arranging for a mode of transportation. Similarly for effects, when the event is in progress then that person is no longer in their origin country. These types of pre- and post-conditional knowledge and inferences are necessary for agents to plan, predict, and operate in the real world. This project aimed at developing and evaluating Natural Language Processing (NLP) systems’ abilities to reason about such conditional knowledge.

One of the key hurdles to developing AI systems is having the necessary data with which to build and evaluate such systems. This project made several important contributions in this respect. It created many resources to drive evaluations of the performance of models on various reasoning tasks. The following are its major contributions:

One contribution was a resource of simple everyday stories aligned with a databank of questions about why certain events occur in these stories. It also includes human-authored answers to these questions. Using these questions, one can test NLP system abilities to understand common situations and to use knowledge about goals, causes, and effects of simple events.

A second resource contribution relates to the problem of understanding how the states of a participant in a scenario can enable or hinder events within the scenario. For example, if water is spilled in a story, then one might assume a state of the water bottle’s lid in which it may not have been tight. This state is compatible with the spilling event. This project created and released a resource that includes a large number of simple narratives along with a set of compatible and incompatible participant states.

As a third resource, this project developed simple yes/no questions about plans (e.g. cooking recipes) and their logical coherence. The main idea is to ask systems to answer if a pair of steps within the plan are actually dependent on each other. This simple test can evaluate a system’s reasoning capabilities, such as identifying enabling conditions for steps, as well as their effects and the results of executing these steps. These dependencies are critical for building applications where autonomous systems are allowed to plan and act in the real world.

A fourth contribution was in developing an evaluation framework for autonomous agents that can complete everyday digital tasks on our behalf. Many tasks require operating multiple applications (apps) in a specific order but in an interactive manner. Responsible development of such autonomous agents requires rigorous and reliable evaluation. This project created mock implementations of apps such as shopping, banking, and others in order to build a testing environment, where agents could complete tasks (e.g. ordering red tshirts under 50 dollars) autonomously. This requires agents to reason about the necessary conditions before executing certain actions, their effects after execution, and to carry out a series of actions that lead to the goal’s completion. 

Overall the project resulted in a set of evaluation resources that helped benchmark, understand and improve the state-of-the-art techniques of NLP systems in reasoning about real world events and actions using pre- and post- condition knowledge.
